body: Good feature proposal ! How do you want to implement the feature ? Unregister the last X models ?

On second thought, if you want to rollback "product" stage model, seemingly you can call `transition_model_version_stage` API to transition this model back to "staging" stage, does this satisfy your demand ?

@WeichenXu123 This is actually not about transitioning the same model version between stages (e.g. moving model version 3 from Production to Staging), rather it is concerned with moving back to a previous model version _within a given stage_.
For instance, model version 3 was in Production previously and it was working fine. After a while, you decide to move model version 7 into production. However, you find out that there is a bug in this new version (version 7) and you want to move back to a version that you know was working properly (version 3). 
When you have a large number of versions registered, it is difficult to keep in mind which model version to go back to (if you are making direct transitions, say by using the `transition_model_version_stage` API). This is why I think this feature might be useful.
We could also maybe provide several options along with this, such as moving back to the first model version in a stage or rollback n times and so on.

@MinuraPunchihewa Got it.
What do you think of this solution:

Add a API like : `rollback_model_to_version(rollback_version, stage)`

it will do: for all models in the `stage` and version larger than `rollback_version`, transition their stage to be "archived".

@WeichenXu123 We would need to specify which model version we are trying to rollback to here, yes? If we knew which model version we need to go back to, then we can simply use `transition_model_version_stage` like you mentioned previously.
The rollback operation, in my opinion, is useful when we don't know which version we want go back to, like I have mentioned in my example. With rollbacks, we are trying to move back to one of the previous versions that were in the stage.

A couple of notes,
- I think this is most useful when we want to maintain one version of a model in a given stage
- I am not completely aware if MLflow keeps a track of the various transitions that take place or all of the model versions that have been in a stage

@MinuraPunchihewa Understood.

> I think this is most useful when we want to maintain one version of a model in a given stage.

Why you need to only keep one model in a given stage ?

If you allow multiple model versions in a stage, and each time you add a new model into given stage, keep old models stage unchanged, then, e.g. in product stage, when you want to rollback to previous product model version, you can transition the latest produce model to "archived" stage, then you can call `get_latest_versions(stage='product')` then you get the previous version product model.

@WeichenXu123 That's clear. But, in my organization, we prefer to maintain only a single model version in Production (in Staging as well, but that is not as important). The version in Production is the model that actually runs in the Production environment.

MLflow already facilitates this through the UI by transitioning model versions that already exist in a given stage to Archived,
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49385643/177271101-1c673cbf-c2b7-4d61-8e9a-d5b85869cc9e.png)

This is also supported in the `transition_model_version_stage` API through the `archive_existing_versions ` flag.

What is your experience on how other organizations approach this? I was under the impression that most organizations would want only one version in certain stages, especially in Production (definitely not in None and Archived though).

Got it. CC @dbczumar What's the best practice for model stage setting ? (suppose we need to support rollback to previous version easily). If our best practice is only keep one model version in product stage, then it cannot easily support rollback to previous version (in this case we are hard to get the previous version)

Workaround for user: Set a tag every time the model version is transitioned to staging or production. To roll back, query the API to list the model versions. Find the maximum model version # that has the tag for staging / production
@WeichenXu123 That's a great idea! Can this be incorporated into a MLflow API as well?
@MinuraPunchihewa Sure! We need to add API to query model by tags. Are you interested in contributing it ?
